POR.DRECONTENT:
Grid-connected residential photovoltaic (PV) systems play an increasingly important part in today's energy market, especially as the number of systems in use continues to grow. For these systems to be effective and reliable, PV control schemes that maintain maximum power output under any environmental condition, as well as under transients are required. While there are numerous maximum power point tracking (MPPT) algorithms, little attention has been paid to examining the PV's natural electrical characteristics and developing a control scheme that has inherently low sensitivity to typical irradiance and temperature changes.

This research investigated a new control scheme for PVs that is less sensitive to typical transients than traditional control. This control scheme is a constant resistance with a voltage offset and was compared to other PV control schemes: constant-voltage, constant-current, and constant-resistance control. The parameters of each control were calculated to operate a string of a PV panel at its maximum power point (MPP). Using equivalent circuit models for crystalline PV cells and typical temperature and irradiance changes, the voltage offset and resistance value yielding the lowest sensitivity was calculated such that the operating point was closest to the new MPP after a transient. An example is shown in Figure 1.

This new control scheme and the traditional control schemes were tested on a PV panel at different irradiance levels using a controlled lighting setup. Each control was implemented on the panel using an electronic load. The results are shown in Figure 2. A control line that maintains operation closest the maximum power point after the transient generates the most power. The voltage-offset-constant-resistance control showed best performance with constant-voltage control as a close second. The constant-resistance control is less effective, but stable for all transients. Constant-current control is ineffective and becomes unstable under large transients.

This research was conducted over summer 2010 at Seoul National University in collaboration with the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign as part of the East Asian and Pacific Summer Institutes (EAPSI) program. This research contributes to advancements in efficient, reliable, and low-cost solar energy captures systems; reducing negative environmental impacts of traditional power generation. This international collaboration was both a technical and cultural learning experience for both involved parties and has developed important connections for future collaboration.
